subtitle: Thinking Allowed Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is crystallized thinking, or
perhaps it could be thinking about crystals
and crystallization.
My guest is my good friend, James Tunney.
He is the author of The Mystical Accord, Sutras
to Suit Our Times, Lines for Spiritual Evolution.
Also, The Mystery of the Trapped Light, Mystical
Thoughts in the Dark Age of Scientism, Empire
of Scientism, the Dispiriting Conspiracy and
Inevitable Tyranny of Scientocracy, Tech Bondage,
Slavery of the Human Spirit, Human Entrance
to Transhumanism, Machine Merger and the End
of Humanity, and most recently, Plantation of the Automatons.
James lives in Gothenburg, Sweden.
And now, I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome James.
Once again, it's a pleasure to be with you.
It's great to see your liquid crystal face again.
Well, I had an interesting insight this morning about our topic.
I was originally thinking of calling it crystallization of consciousness.
And then it occurred to me, consciousness is
probably, at least in terms of pure spirit,
can never be crystallized.
It's infinite in a way.
What gets crystallized isn't consciousness per se.
It's something that rests above consciousness
that you could call thinking or mentation.
Yeah, I think you've hit the nub of the matter.
We don't have to proceed beyond that, Jeff.
That was very, very astute.
That's right.
And I think there's a great problem here in
that people who are interested in consciousness
from a very reductionist, ultra-materialist
perspective, they tend to focus on the carrier
of consciousness and not the content of consciousness.
And if you look at people who are very well-informed
in both contexts, like Penrose, he in the
end says that mathematics won't be able to explain consciousness.
And that is interesting, coming from a person
who understands crystals and crystallography,
and I think is in favor of a more generalized
idea of crystallography, recognizing that
it's a pervasive idea.
And he has worked on the minutiae of how consciousness works.
But in a lot of cases, what these people are
doing, the good ones, are identifying the
basis on which are the conditions for consciousness to operate on.
And if you look at people like Federico Faggin
and others, they seem to be suggesting, really,
that the human physical form operates in a way that makes us receptive, or quantumly
receptive.
So mentation, I think that's a very good idea, as
you've described it, and it refers or indicates
the fundamental nature of crystals.
And I tend to, more and more, think that we
should change our idea of crystals more away
from the noun to the verb, to the crystal state,
and recognize that, as you have suggested,
our thinking process refers to a context whereby
a structure is formed in a diverse element,
and sometimes we're too crystallized.
But I think that's right.
Consciousness is too complex to be reduced to some elements.
It may be that, in future, the conception
of consciousness is more determined in terms
of, there's an idea of, there's an E8 crystal,
for example, a complex crystal, but it could
be regarded as a series of interlocking crystalline
structures, but still there will be something
bigger than the individual elements.
While we do tend to get crystallized, you could be crystallized as a parapsychologist
or as a Marxist or as a Catholic or as a patriot,
at the same time there's always the potential
for consciousness, pure consciousness, to break through the crystallization.
Yes, that's very well put, and people like Stendhal,
the German writer, wrote about crystallization,
the psychology of crystallization in relation
to love, for example, he uses the process
of salt crystallization to explain psychologically how we work.
As a result of this and my study of crystals,
I've come to an idea that there's a very basic
dichotomy in a lot of human thinking, and
this is related to what you said, and it comes
down to a situation where people form a worldview
which is essentially crystalline, and as a
result of that, they see the human as being
effectively in a crystal state, and they believe
that there's associated political views associated
with the state they live in, and some of these
also want to create a world state, so the
state also, when we think of that, has a number
of different connotations, and so that focuses
on form and structure, and crystals are defined
in essence by the lattice structure, if we take
a chessboard, for example, a simple lattice
structure indicates the orderliness and arrangement
of the internal structure of crystals, and
there seems to be a desire from certain people
to extrapolate from that orderliness to the
imposition of an orderliness on society, an
arrangement on society, and on the other side,
there are people who prioritize and privilege
consciousness, and realize that consciousness
is above the crystalline form, that the content
of consciousness is something different, and
I would argue that this is more in accord with
my and many other people's ideas of consciousness
as light, so there's an intense and very close
nexus between crystalline structure and light,
on the LCD screens, we have the light and the liquid crystals, the internal structure
of crystals was really made available through
the technology of x-rays, so x-rays enabled
this application of the x-rays to crystals, enabled people like Max von Lauer and the
Bragg family, and Bernal and all the other great crystallographers to look inside and
to understand through the diffraction pattern of
atoms and molecules, how the internal structure
was, and that was the important technology, so we have the connection between light and
molecules, and in spiritual terms, we could look at Jacob Boehme, who talked really in
terms of spiritual alchemy, and he has a kind
of salt in the middle of mercury and sulfur,
now salt of course is a crystal, if we go
back to Jesus in the Bible, in Matthew, Jesus

he says also that you can lose your saltiness,
and then he proceeds to say that you should
shine your light and not hide your light under

an important aspect of our form, but the light
is the primary influence, and I would equate
that light with consciousness, so we mustn't
confuse the macro world of consciousness with
its micro manifestations, and we mustn't confuse
the content with the carrier, and that's where
the real nub of the matter, a lot of people
that believe that they can control consciousness,
believe that it's merely a matter of a rearrangement
of the human mind and the human physiology, so that they become less unpredictable, and
in that way, of course, we'd lose free will.
There is a sense, if you take a prism, for example, which is a crystalline form, and
you shine light through it, then the light
can radiate into different colors, white light
becomes a whole rainbow of colors, so the
relationship between the light of consciousness
and the crystallization of form is very important.
Yes, but we get similar effects, whether we
use glass or crystals, and some of the things
depending on the planes that are available,
but if you even look at, there's a difference
of emphasis between Newton and Goethe in relation
to how light behaved, and Goethe criticized

insights that Newton had, but about the nature
and the conduct of experiments, about how
Newton did the experiment, and Goethe realized
that that wasn't the full story, that in fact,
he noticed in daylight and in ordinary context,
and looking through certain glasses, that
the color appears between darkness and light,
and this is an important thing that people forget.
If we come along with a Newtonian idea, we can fail to see some of the deeper insights
that come about from a different perspective,
and associated with the idea of crystals is
a fundamental idea that crystals enable us to access different dimensions.
There's a fundamental aspect of dimensionality
about that, so crystals are on the cusp or
between different worlds, that's why they're
used in communication devices, they're used
in quartz, is used in computers and communication
devices, and I remember you talking in one

Mr. Simmons, when you talked about crystals,
about your crystal radio, and a lot of people
don't realize that you can make a radio with

Sometimes they use foxhole radios, they were
used during the war, but that's the same process
again, the crystal enables us to access a different world.
Now, one little point on this, crystals have
been used in the ancient world, and people
knew this, they knew some of these elements,
if we take the mythic and legendary places
like Atlantis, people like Cayce said that crystals were the important technology that
were used there according to his visions, but
we see that, we'll take the Irish example,
in all the ancient sites there is quartz is found, and there's various theories about

their electrical, they may have been used
for their electrical effects, and one of the
words, there's a number of words for the quartz
in the Irish language, there may be pluck,
is a word for stone, so there may be pluck, galla, or green pluck, associated with the
sun, sunstone, or there may be pluck oostla,
which means the noble stone, and that word
oostla, the same word was used in relation to
the fairies, and they're found in the sites
associated with the fairies, so this is again
about the other dimensionality associated
with crystals, and that trend went right up
from the various writings in the Greeks, through

stone, to people on the cusp of modern science

for example, a communication with other worlds.
So it's funny that crystals are very structured in

we can see that it's also about transformation,
about mutability, and about creating links

well, more recently, I'm thinking that our

other ideas of plasmodic crystals and photonic
crystals associated with reflection of light,
for example, in a peacock's tail.
I'm reminded of the biblical story of, I believe, if I recall correctly, Lot's wife.
During the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah,
she turned and looked back and was turned
into a pillar of salt.
That came into my head, funnily enough, today,
and I was thinking about that, and it's funny,
and now again, without relying on this very unduly literalistic reading of the context,
because that's, people like Swedenborg and
that say you have to look at these on different

of the divine punishment was turning into

view, well, we can take another view, because

say, well, this is curiosity, and this ties in with the prodigal son example, and why

when we're talking about the Old Testament context.
But on another view, on a different level, here, there is an example, independently of

represents a reduction to purely crystalline
form without anything else.
So in that context, you might argue that the

So the pillar of salt represents, in some ways, this, the deadliness of only relying

There could be that reading in relation to, there is, crystals were critical in Judaism

So there is this idea of ancient technology,
but yeah, I think in some ways that Lot's

Well certainly there is this notion, and perhaps

That's right, and I'm glad you mentioned him

Bernal fit in with those great crystallographers,

As well as working on the structure of water,
and we've talked to your nephew, who was telling

Well Bernal worked on that.
He also worked on graphite, and graphite of

So Bernal was also working on basically the

There was also Rosalind Franklin, and Ashbery had worked on that as well.
And another thing that people forget about is, we've talked about crystals and plants
are very much connected, and a lot of the
advances in relation to crystals are associated
with investigations in relation to plants.
So one of the things they were investigating
was the tobacco, the structure of the tobacco
mosaic virus, and this was something that botanists had studied in the 19th century.
Now you don't have to be a genius to work out
why, because tobacco was a valuable product
associated with colonialism, and any virus
that affected that had consequences, and that
was why they investigated it, and later on
in the 1930s they came up with the structure
of this virus, but the word virus and virology comes from that plant context.
It doesn't come from the human context.
The use of virus as we understand it comes from that plant context.
So virology as well came into this study of crystallography, as well as that we have to

in 1942 and 1943, which was published as What
is Life, and in that he anticipated the DNA by identifying the possibility that it was
an aperiodic crystal.
So life itself was seen to be, by some, a crystal objective.

despite his great crystallography, he was
a Stalinist, and he said, of course, that in

that scientific corporations would take over the

people that didn't want to do that would live
